snippet: Some experts say the system, relying heavily on the honesty of travelers and the diligence of airport workers, could quickly be overwhelmed by rapidly spreading disease.
abstract: Arrival in United States of Liberian man infected with Ebola virus shows how difficult it is to control or restrict the disease from spreading, and how porous current procedures are in world of globalized air travel; some experts say system, relying heavily on honesty of travelers and the diligence of airport workers, could quickly be overwhelmed by rapidly spreading disease.

byline.original: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and JAD MOUAWAD
byline.contributor: Norimitsu Onishi reported from Monrovia, and Jad Mouawad from New York. Reporting was contributed by Matthew L. Wald from New York; Michael D. Shear and Ron Nixon from Washington; Sheri Fink from Monrovia; Adam Nossiter from Freetown, Sierra Leone; and Gina Kolata from New York.

lead_paragraph: Some experts say the system, relying heavily on the honesty of travelers and the diligence of airport workers, could quickly be overwhelmed by rapidly spreading disease.

headline.main: Ebola Patient’s Journey Shows How Global Travel Spreads Disease
headline.print_headline: Journey Illustrates How Global Travel Is Open to the Spread of Disease
